text: I'm Neil dwani co-director of the
advanced cybercity program at Stanford
online and your guide through the world
of cyber security jobs today I'm going
to debunk the top five myths surrounding
these careers let's get
started myth number one you have to be a
computer genius to get a cyber security
job having a technical background helps
but you don't need to be a PhD rocket
scientist the cyber security field has
evolved and is much larger and more
diverse than it used to be there are now
jobs like cyber security project and
product managers that are more business
focused and pseudo technical we need a
diverse range of skills and expertise
soft skills and communication skills are
also super important think of it like
the Star Wars Universe there are a few
Elite Jedi highly skilled and Technical
but we also need a much larger Army a
kind of a rebel alliance to defend our
digital
landscape myth number two you'll need to
learn everything from scratch and it can
take years I'm here to tell you that's
not the case either if you have a
foundation in Information Technology
computer science or management
information systems you can be job ready
in as little as 3 months to a year with
the right resources and training even if
you don't have the right or the perfect
degree courses like foundations of
information security from Stanford
online can help with giving you the
fundamentals you need to make cyber
security contributions myth number three
only big companies hire cyber Security
Professionals that's a misconception
organizations of all sizes need cyber
Security Professionals working for them
just think about all the recent
ransomware attacks on city or state
governments they need cyber Security
Experts to protect their data and keep
their systems up and running the demand
for skilled professionals exists across
Industries and
sectors myth number four the hours and
pay for cyber security are not good
let's dispel that myth many of the roles
like in engineering offer manageable
work schedules some roles such as
incident response teams do indeed have
intense hours especially during security
incidents but roles like security
operations analysts rotate with three
shifts over a 24-hour period as for the
pay the median annual salary for an
information security analyst is well
over
$100,000 and with more than 20,000 new
vulnerabilities getting logged in the
National vulnerability database every
year there's little chance of that
cooling there are hundreds of thousands
of open cyber security positions in the
us alone and millions
worldwide myth number five cyber
security is a narrow field not anymore
the scope of cyber security has expanded
a lot over the past 20 years companies
governments and individuals spend more
than a hundred billion on Cyber secur
Solutions every year so it's a broader
field than ever today there are
countless opportunities and specialities
from cyber security analysts to Chief
information security officers and
everything in between
so as you can see many of the myths
surrounding cyber security jobs simply
no longer hold true the field is more
accessible and diverse than ever before
if you're interested in exploring a
career in cyber security or improving
your existing skills I invite you to try
one of the courses in Stanford's
Advanced cyber security program it'll
give you the knowledge and tools you
need to succeed
[Music]
